children.name: shipwreck
children.definition: the destruction of a ship in an accident : đắm tàu
examples: survivors of the shipwreck
narrowly escaping shipwreck
The danger of shipwreck is much greater in fog.
There have been many shipwrecks along this dangerous stretch of coastline.

children.name: accident
children.definition: an event in which a car, train, plane etc is damaged and often someone is hurt :
examples: Over 70,000 people are seriously injured every year in road accidents.
The accident happened at the junction of Forest Road and Pine Walk.
a train accident
accident rates/statisticsThere is a relation between accident rates and the numbers of drivers on the road.|a survey of the latest airline accident statistics
COMMON ERRORS
►Do not say 'a small accident'. Saya minor accident.

children.name: a bad/serious accident
examples: There’s been a bad accident on the freeway.|The road is closed following a serious accident.

children.name: a major accident
examples: News is coming in of a major rail accident.

children.name: a horrible/nasty/horrific accident
examples: We narrowly avoided a nasty accident.|‘This was an absolutely horrific accident,’ said an ambulance spokesman.

children.name: a fatal accident
children.definition: in which someone is killed
examples: a fatal accident involving a bus and a cyclist

children.name: a minor accident
children.definition: one that is not serious
examples: The ice and poor visibility caused minor accidents all over the country.

children.name: a road/traffic accident
examples: The number of traffic accidents has gone down.|Portugal has one of Western Europe’s worst road accident rates.

children.name: a car accident
children.definition: alsoan automobile accidentAmerican English formal
examples: He was badly injured in a car accident.

children.name: a plane accident/an airplane accident
children.definition: alsoa flying accident
examples: Holly died in a plane accident.

children.name: a rail accident/a train accident
examples: It was the country's worst ever rail accident.

children.name: a hit-and-run accident
children.definition: when someone is hit by a driver who does not stop
examples: A woman is fighting for her life after a hit-and-run accident.

children.name: have an accident
examples: I had an accident on my way to work.

children.name: be involved in an accidentformal
examples: Your son has been involved in a car accident.

children.name: prevent an accident
examples: Steps have been taken to prevent a similar accident happening again.

children.name: an accident happens
children.definition: alsoan accident occursformal
examples: No one saw the accident happen.|Most road accidents occur in urban areas.

children.name: an accident victim
examples: One of the accident victims is still trapped in his vehicle.

children.name: an accident investigation/inquiry
examples: The two deaths are the subject of an accident inquiry.|Accident investigations often take months.

children.name: an accident investigator
examples: Accident investigators have been there all morning.

children.name: the scene of an accident
children.definition: the place where it happened
examples: Police were at the scene of the accident within minutes.

children.name: crash
children.definition: a serious accident in which a vehicle hits something else :
examples: Forty-one people were killed in a plane crash.
crash between/with
a motorway crash between a coach and a lorry
She was involved ina head-on crashwith a motorbike
a high-speed crashthe risk of injury from a high-speed crash
a horrific/terrible/appalling crasha horrific crash in which three teenage boys were killed

children.name: a car/train/plane etc crash
examples: He was badly hurt in a car crash.

children.name: a road/rail/air crash
examples: There will be an investigation into the cause of the air crash.

children.name: a head-on crash
children.definition: in which the front part of two vehicles hit each other
examples: He died in a head-on crash with a lorry.

children.name: a fatal crash
children.definition: in which someone is killed
examples: There have been several fatal crashes on this road.

children.name: have a crash
children.definition: alsobe involved in a crash
examples: (= in a car )I’ve been nervous about driving since I had a crash last year.

children.name: a crash happens/occurs
examples: The three-vehicle crash happened on the corner of Ongar Road.

children.name: a crash involves something
examples: Two women were taken to hospital after a crash involving a bus and a car.

children.name: a crash victim
children.definition: someone injured or killed in a crash
examples: Families of the crash victims want to know what happened.

children.name: a crash site/scene
children.definition: place where a crash happens
examples: The authorities closed off a five-mile area around the crash site.

children.name: a crash investigator
children.definition: someone who tries to find the cause of a crash
examples: Crash investigators spent several days examining the scene.

children.name: wreck
children.definition: US an accident in which a car or train is badly damaged :
examples: Nobody could have survived the wreck.

children.name: car/train/plane wreck
examples: My father died in a car wreck.
Ben nearly died in a car wreck.

children.name: pile-up
children.definition: a seriousroadaccident in whichmanycars or other vehicles crash into each other:vụ đâm nhau
examples: The pile-up happened in thick fog and caused a seven-mile tailback on the motorway
multiple pile-up UK a pile up involving a large number of carsvụ tai nạn nhiều xe
a multiple pile-up involving a minibus and five cars

children.name: disaster
children.definition: a very serious accident involving atrain,plane, orship, in whichmany people are killed:thảm họa
examples: The city has emergency plans for dealing with a major disaster such as a rail crash.

children.name: air/rail disasterthảm hoạ hàng không, đường ray
examples: At least 264 people died, in one of the worst civilian air disasters of all time.

children.name: the Lockerbie disaster/the Challenger disaster etc
examples: The Challenger disaster cost the lives of seven astronauts, and set back the nation’s space program for years.

children.name: collision
children.definition: an accident in whichtwoormorevehicles, planes, or ships hit each other:va đụng, vụ đâu nhau

children.name: collision with
examples: A school bus has been involved in a collision with a fuel tanker.
His car was involved in a collision with a train.

children.name: mid-air collisionbetween two planes in the airva đụng trên không
examples: The risk of a mid-air collision over central London has increased dramatically.

children.name: head-on collisionbetween two vehicles moving directly towards each other
examples: These airbags are designed to protect car drivers in head-on collisions.
The actor was killed in a head-on collision while driving his new sports car.
Two drivers were killed in ahead-oncollisionbetweena car and a taxi last night.

children.name: in collision with
examples: The cyclist wasincollisionwitha bus.

children.name: prang
children.definition: UK/ fender-benderUS informala car accident in which little damage is done : tai nạn nhẹ, va chạm nhẹ
examples: Atkinson was involved in a fender-bender in the hotel parking lot.
At 15, he borrowed his parents’ car and had a prang.

children.name: when a vehicle, ship etc turns over in an accident
turn over
children.definition: /ˌtɜːʳn ˈəʊvəʳ/  if a vehicle turns over, it turns upside down, especially as a result of an accident: lật úp
examples: ▪ The car smashed into the post, turned over, and burst into flames.
▪ The train was travelling so fast that when it came off the rails it turned over onto its roof.

children.name: capsize
children.definition: if a boat capsizes, or sb/sth capsizes it, it turns over in the water: lật úp

children.name: ▪ The ship capsized in rough waters with the loss of 208 lives
examples: ▪ People were fighting for places in the lifeboat, and there was a real danger of it capsizing.
▪ A huge wave struck the side of our boat, almost capsizing it.
A huge wave capsized the yacht.
When the boat capsized we were trapped underneath it.

children.name: roll over
children.definition: /ˌrəʊl ˈəʊvəʳ/  if a vehicle or ship rolls over, it turns upside down because it is not correctly balanced:
examples: ▪ The truck jack-knifed and then rolled over.
▪ Ships have stabilizers to prevent them from rolling over in rough seas.

children.name: overturn
children.definition: if a vehicle or boat overturns, or someone or something overturns it, it turns over: lật úp
examples: ▪ The truck had overturned, but the driver was not injured.
▪ The whole crew was drowned when their boat overturned in a storm.
▪ During the riots several cars were overturned and set on fire.

children.name: hit
children.definition: /hɪt/
examples: ▪ The bus hit a tree and the driver was badly injured.
▪ He pulled out of the driveway without looking, and almost hit another car.
▪ Five sailors were killed when their ship hit a mine.

children.name: hit sb head-ondirectly
examples: ▪ The driver of a Ford van lost control and hit another car head-on.

children.name: run over
children.definition: to hit and injure a person or animal while driving a vehicle: cán
examples: I'm afraid we've just run a rabbit over.
How can you run over a child and not stop?

children.name: be run over by sth
examples: The boy’s dog had been run over by a car.

children.name: get run over
examples: Make sure the lights on your bike are working. I don’t want you getting run over.

children.name: crash into
children.definition: /smash into to hit sb/sth very hard while you are driving a vehicle, making a lot of noise and causing damage:
examples: The driver lost control on a curve and crashed into a tree.
An airplane had crashed into a mountain, killing all two hundred passengers.

children.name: go crashing into something
examples: The car skidded, then went crashing into the bus shelter.
An army helicopter smashed into the side of the mountain.

children.name: run into
children.definition: to hit something that is directly in front of you with your vehicle, especially because you are not paying attention:
examples: I turned too sharply and ran into the curb.
We almost ran into a Rolls-Royce that pulled out in front of us without signalling.
He ran into the car in front while he was talking on his mobile phone.
I had to brake suddenly, and the car behind ran into me.

children.name: run sth into
examples: He ran his motorbike into a tree.

children.name: plough into
children.definition: UK /plow intoUS to hit a large number of vehicles or people with a vehicle, especially as a result of driving too fast, not paying attention etc: “cày” , “xới tung”
examples: The bus went out of control and ploughed into a line of traffic.
Many people were injured when the train came off the rails and ploughed into the bank.
The car went out of control and ploughed into a group of people on the sidewalk.
When the driver fell asleep, the bus ploughed into a line of traffic.

children.name: collide
children.definition: to hit sth or sb that is moving in a different direction from you: đâm nhau
examples: A car and a van collided on the motorway.
The two planes collided in mid-air.
An express train collided with a freight train in the morning rush hour.

children.name: collide with
examples: I ran around the corner, and almost collided with Mrs Laurence.
Two trainscollided head-on(= when they were moving directly towards each other ).
RegisterIn everyday English, people usually sayrun intorather thancollide with:
Her carran intothe back of a truck.

children.name: ram
children.definition: to deliberately hit another boat or vehicle very hard, especially when it is not moving : tông
examples: The ship had been rammed by a submarine.
The gunmen tried to ram the police car.
In the latest raid, thieves used his van to ram a police car.

children.name: go into
children.definition: UK informal to hit sb/sth with a vehicle:
examples: Someone went into the back of my bike at the traffic lights.

children.name: list
children.definition: (of a ship) to lean to one side, especially as a result of damage : nghiêng qua một bên
examples: The tanker is listing badly and liable to sink at any moment.

children.name: have an accident
children.definition: gặp tai nạn
examples: You shouldn’t go so fast on that motorcycle, you’ll have an accident!

children.name: crash
children.definition: to have a serious accident in a car, train, plane etc by violently hitting another vehicle or sth such as a wall or the ground:đâm sầm
examples: He lost control of his car at the first bend and crashed.
The plane crashed shortly after take-off.
The jet crashed after take-off.

children.name: crash into/onto etc
examples: The plane crashed into a mountain.

children.name: crash a car/bus/plane etc
examples: He was drunk when he crashed the car.

children.name: involved in an accident
children.definition: be formalto have an accident - used inofficialwrittendocuments and innewsreports:gặp tai nạn
examples: If you are involved in an accident, wearing a seat belt will have the risk of death.
Stolen cars are more likely to be involved in accidents.

children.name: a ship or vehicle that has been damaged
wreck
children.definition: a car, plane, or train that has been damaged very badly, especially in a crash : xác xe
examples: He was still alive when they pulled him from the wreck.
The burned-out wrecks of two police cars littered the road.

children.name: wreck
children.definition: / shipwrecka ship that has sunk : xác tàu
examples: Divers exploring the wreck managed to salvage some coins and jewellery.

children.name: wreck of
examples: Divers discovered the wreck of an old German warship.
